awd_titl_txt: GOALI:Cooperative Integration of High Efficiency Multijunction Solar Cell Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop a multijunction solar cell which has the potential to exceed the current record solar-to-electric energy conversion efficiency of 41.6%. This cell uses a tandem germanium/gallium arsenide/indium gallium phosphide structure, which is limited by the current generated in the top two cells. The approach is to integrate strained layer superlattices into both of these cells in order to reduce the bandgap. The resulting potentially significant increase in the current generated by the top and middle cells with only a small decrease in voltage, should improve the efficiency of the multijunction photovoltaic device.

This work will impact the science of photovoltaic devices and strained layer superlattices. The ability to extend the optical absorption of the solar spectrum beyond that of conventional GaAs solar cells has been a long-standing problem since the demonstration of the first multijunction PV device. The proposed work will extend this absorption region while maintaining lattice matching of dissimilar materials, and thus carrier lifetimes. Strained layer superlattices have wide applicability in other applications as well, such as photodetectors and optical modulators for high frequency communications and sensing.

Photovoltaic materials have the potential to provide a clean and renewable energy source. The project will train students in a number of skills used in the semiconductor industry such as growth, fabrication, characterization and device modeling. This will include the participation of undergraduate, minority students, and high school students and teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The achievement of high efficiencies in multijunction concentrator photovoltaics requires the development of new technologies to effectively collect solar energies. The lattice-matched three junction InGaP/GaAs/Ge structure suffers from an excess of current in the Ge subcell due to the non-ideal band gaps of the InGaP and GaAs. We have developed strain balanced quantum well (QW) structures that can be inserted into the intrinsic layer of a p-i-n structure to lower the effective band gap of the top two cells. Since the compressive QW material is grown with a strain compensating tensile barrier material, these structures can be grown without the formation of defects that are present in metamorphic cells.

An InGaAs-well GaAsP-barrier QW structure was developed to lower the band gap of the GaAs subcells. p-i-n structures were grown that extended the absorption to 1.25 eV. Such structures showed an increase in the short circuit current with little decrease in open circuit voltage and fill factor. The same approach was used for the InGaP cells with InGaAsP wells and InGaP barriers, with the absorption extended to 1.5 eV. These approaches can be used to improve the effiency of three junction cells and the strain balanced QW concept can be extended to other material systems for four, five and six junction structures.

The tunnel junction (TJ) between the GaAs and InGaP subcells is also an issue as often a compromise must be made between a structure composed of semiconductors with band gaps above 1.9 eV, which limits the maximum solar concentration, and a GaAs containing TJ, which will reduce the total efficiency due to the parasitic absorption of light. We hav developed a high band gap tunnel junction structure that will allow triple junction cells to operate at concentrations of 2000 suns and above.

A drastic improvement in the performance of the n-InGaP/p-AlGaAs TJ was observed when a thin (30-50 Å) layer of GaAs was placed at the junction interface. This resulted in TJ devices with as-grown peak tunneling currents (Jpk) as high as 2000 A/cm2 and Jpk above 1000 A/cm2 for devices annealed under simulated top cell growth conditions. These two results represent a world record performance for both as-grown and annealed high bandgap tunnel junctions. The annealed device has a Jpk suitable for solar concentrations above 65,000 suns, well above the requirements for practical solar concentrators.

These results will allow for flexability in the design of multijunction solar cells by tuning the bandgap below 1.4 and 1.85 eV. Also, for the tunnel junction we have solved one of the problems that was limiting the pefromance of multijunction concentrators and have achieved a world record for the TJ performance. This program has resulted in the graduation of Ph.D. students, Geoff Bradshaw and Zachary Carlin and has also allowed us to recruit Brandon Hagar as an undergraduate to work on this project and progress to graduate level work.
